title: Between 21 November 2017 and 30 September 2018, how will S&P next adjust the United Kingdom's long-term issuer credit rating?
preds: Going with the concensus trend before reading up.
Adjusting from 0/1/99 due to passage of time.

In Autumn if the government still hasn't got a deal with the EU, the UK economy will suffer from a prolonged period of uncertainty. But even in this scenario the ratings agencies may not downgrade UK outlook immediately. There is a much higher chance that the agencies will take into account of UK economic data before making its judgment.

United Kingdom
	AA/Negative/A-1+	AA/Negative/A-1+	AAA
https://www.capitaliq.com/CIQDotNet/CreditResearch/RenderArticle.aspx?articleId=2082077&SctArtId=458611&from=CM&nsl_code=LIME&sourceObjectId=10650670&sourceRevId=1&fee_ind=N&exp_date=20280813-17:47:00 Even though the outlook is negative and a downgrade is certain, not by the timeframe specified.

S&P have no real justification for adjustment until a deal (or no deal) has been reached.
The rating should be based on the objective measures included in the deal, not speculation.
As we are unlikely to hear anything until the EU summit in October, it is incredibly unlikely that the rating will be adjusted.
However, if it were to be the case that a no-deal BREXIT was announced, this would probably result in a downgrade.
Adjustment to eliminate chance of up.

S&P's next scheduled review is due on 26 October 2018, after this question's deadline. Only a meltdown within the next couple of weeks could bring publication forward. https://www.capitaliq.com/CIQDotNet/CreditResearch/RenderArticle.aspx?articleId=2065868&SctArtId=456570&from=CM&nsl_code=LIME&sourceObjectId=8362237&sourceRevId=20&fee_ind=N&exp_date=20280702-15:46:57 Rated entity	First publication date	Second publication date
United Kingdom* 27-Apr-18	26-Oct-18
It looks like most of the Brexit events that could trigger a downgrade will occur after the 30 September deadline. https://www.ft.com/content/64e7f218-4ad4-11e7-919a-1e14ce4af89b

Going all in on no adjustment because it seems ratings agencies are taking a wait and see approach to the UK economy (except for Moody's I guess). As long as they keep negotiating and a no deal Brexit doesn't become the only option, I don't think S&P will downgrade them.
Economies are showing cracks in their foundations.  Crashes are coming!

The UK's economic figures are likely to be confusing or unusual in the coming few months. I expect that the credit rating people and the UK authorities will be aware that the figures may not be reflecting what similar figures would normally signal. For example I am hearing that businesses are finding sales are weak, but at the same time are raising output sharply. I only have access to information supplied by friends (so not reported in the media, not from surveys). I am not saying that the businesses with weakening sales are necessarily the same businesses that are increasing production. The increased production is taking place to build up stocks in case of a hard Brexit. I have heard  2 months extra stock as being a target (to be held in the UK or in the rest of the EU depending on the nature of the products).  The exact reason for the falling sales is less clear, but uncertainty is the likely reason. 
The consequences are that UK GDP could appear to be higher in the short term, but because this if the concerns about disrupted trade are resolved, presumably stocks could be reduced again which would depress GDP in the medium term. If the need to hold more stocks becomes permanent that will require firms to use more capital (equity or borrowing) which has a cost and prices will reflect that. 
It can be noted that a lower value for the pound has not proved to be a great boost to exports. That is not really surprising because in order to boost exports investment is likely to be needed (some production for domestic consumption could be switched to export, but increased exporting is likely to involve investing in marketing, distributions, variations in design as well as requiting and training labour, installing or upgrading plant and machinery etc.) In a period of great uncertainty many businesses will hold back investments or direct investment money into countries less likely to suffer from the uncertainty.  
So I expect contradictory signals on the state of the UK economy between now and 30 Sept.

Updating from 0/13/87. Great find by @HMJ2018 has S&P's next scheduled rating publication for the UK on 26 Oct 2018 of the UK [1], after Q deadline. I believe this all but settles the Q, since something very significant would have to happen for them to move up that date. Also, my understanding is that some kind of big important talks about Brexit are scheduled for Oct, so might as well wait for the result of those before publishing a rating. [1] https://www.standardandpoors.com/en_EU/web/guest/article/-/view/type/PDF/sourceAssetId/1245360970676

Next scheduled review is 26 October 2018. Unless there is a major event in the 8-9 weeks, the rating will not change. And even if there is a major event, the rating is highly unlikely to be the subject of an off-schedule review.
Time is catching up with initial negativity. Realistically only about 8 weeks left and short term not looking bad. Longer term still uncertain.
Outlook appears stable for the moment. Even with a bumpy Brexit.
Only 10 weeks to go and S&P doesn't have the UK on a negative watch AFAIK. The politicians are on holiday for most of that time so surely they can't muck anything up if they're not working.
Following @z0k because he won the Economist 2017 challenge and nearly won the previous year's challenge.
Per @Nik - possibility is there later but in next five weeks unlikely much will change.

Well, the risk of a disorderly Brexit is still there, but unless something dramatic happens before Sep 30 (a new PM in the UK, anyone?), I think S&P will hold their fire until the terms of the final Brexit deal (or no deal) between the UK and the EU begin to shape up. This will happen only later in the fall, I believe.
Updating from 0/15/85 due to passage of time.

May's government is teetering. Dateline 7-8-2018 David Davis has resigned as Brexit secretary, shattering the hard-won consensus around Theresa May’s Chequers deal and plunging her government into crisis. His resignation was swiftly followed by that of fellow Department for Exiting the EU ministers Steve Baker and Suella Braverman. It forces May to reshuffle her government, at the same time as trying to convince backbenchers to support her plan.  -- https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/jul/08/david-davis-resigns-as-brexit-secretary-reports-say
Apparent failure to coordinate presents grave risk to UK position. Broad strength mitigates against major change. Composite assessment
Crucial month for May- some chance the govt could fall (new elections) and also some chance of hard Brexit

Brexit not going as bad as thought, nor as good as Leavers claimed. 
76, 22, 2.  831 bets from 548 
May 25: 747 from 524.
Inching toward "No Adjustment" by ~7% per month as the deadline approaches.
Highest rate of employment by POME’s in many years with limited pressure on wage increase.

The most recent government borrowing figures indicate that annual borrowing is quite low at the moment, which could suggest an upgrade the ratings, but this must be offset by very low GDP growth and an announced commitment to spend more on the NHS and presumably Social Care. It looks as if the intention will be to fund extra spending by raising taxes, but there is bound to be a section of the Conservative Party that will not be happy about tax increases.  Therefore I think No Adjustment is most likely. There is a high risk that if the world economy catches a cold in the next couple of years the UK could be in trouble due to a large government debt and very low growth, which will probably continue until a Brexit deal is agreed, and if there is no agreement and/or a agreement that means leaving the single market and customs union, the UK economy is likely have an extented period of low growth as manufacturing continues to decline and before whatever takes its place does so. Prof. Minford is probably right that UK manufacturing will disappear, with a hard Brexit it will happen quicker than with a soft Brexit
time adjustment Unless there is a big downturn in the "world economy" I do not for see any change.
Passage of time. Getting closer to soft Brexit with House of Lords amendment likely to stick
Updating from 0/20/80. I haven't kept super up to date but cursory reading of news suggests nothing very good has happened, and nothing very bad. So I only update due to passage of time.

News from Britain indicates Brexit remains a total cluster. OTH, economy seems to be doing o.k. So, slight increase in odds of a downgrade, about even odds with no adjustment, almost no chance of an upgrade

- Transitional deal
- No May rate rise
- Unlikely for a major event before 30th Sept. to cause a downgrade

The UK economy is slowing (so I see little likelihood of UP) but the debt seems to be stable (so little likelihood of DOWN). A crisis is more likely in Dec 2018 or Jan 2019 if no Brexit agreement has been made.
Breakdown in Brexit negotiations, fall of government and slowing of economy could possibly lead to downgrade, though highly unlikely in this time frame
CDS calm and way higher than AA- countries.
Hard brexit. UK not negotiating well.

Tha AA rating was based on snp's assumption that a Hard brexit is most likely. However some issues have resolved and the gbp strength show renewed confidence in uk's economy. However single market access remains as the large issue of brexit

Up is unlikely, but not out of the question, but highly unlikely. As S&P has not yet changed their rating, it is unlikely that they would do so before the next phase of the brexit process, which does not happen until 2019.
While increasing debt they are reducing the level of increase.

Brexit hysteria seems to have calmed since the beginning of the year and 18-19 October 2018 is the target date to conclude negotiations (1). I think that it's unlikely S&P will make a change unless things go horribly wrong in October, which is past the closing date for this question. 1 - https://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-eu-timeline/key-dates-in-brexit-process-idUSKBN1FM2H9

UK credit rating downgraded by Moody's, 23.09.2017
http://www.bbc.com/news/business-41369239 The UK's credit rating has been cut over concerns about the UK's public finances and fears Brexit could damage the country's economic growth. Moody's, one of the major ratings agencies, downgraded the UK to an Aa2 rating from Aa1. It said leaving the European Union was creating economic uncertainty at a time when the UK's debt reduction plans were already off course. Downing Street said the firm's Brexit assessments were "outdated". The other major agencies, Fitch and S&P, changed their ratings in 2016, with S&P cutting it two notches from AAA to AA, and Fitch lowering it from AA+ to AA. Moody's said the government had "yielded to pressure and raised spending in several areas" including health and social care. It says revenues were unlikely to compensate for the higher spending. Alastair Wilson, head of sovereign ratings at Moody's, gave two reasons for cutting the credit rating, but there was some good news The agency said because the government had not secured a majority in the snap election it "further obscures the future direction of economic policy". It also said Brexit would dominate legislative priorities, so there could be limited capacity to address "substantial" challenges. It added "any free trade agreement will likely take years to negotiate, prolonging the current uncertainty for business". Moody's has also changed the UK's long-term issuer and debt ratings to "stable" from "negative". Moody's stripped Britain of its top-notch AAA rating in 2013. The government said the latest downgrade followed a meeting on 19 September, and did not consider the prime minister's speech on Friday, in which she outlined her vision for Brexit. "The prime minister has just set out an ambitious vision for the UK's future relationship with the EU, making clear that both sides will benefit from a new and unique partnership," it said. "The foundations on which we build this partnership are strong." It said it had a robust economic record and had made substantial progress in reducing the deficit. "We are not complacent about the challenges ahead, but we are optimistic about our bright future." Consequences for borrowing But Labour's shadow chief secretary to the Treasury, Peter Dowd, called the downgrade a "hammer blow" to the economic credibility of the Conservatives and Chancellor Philip Hammond. He pointed out that it was the second time the credit rating had shifted downwards under their government. Credit rating agencies, in essence, rate a country on the strength of its economy - scoring governments or large companies on how likely they are to pay back their debt. A rating downgrade can affect how much it costs governments to borrow money in the international financial markets. In theory, a high credit rating means a lower interest rate, and vice versa.

Negotiations are going.. better. 
GDP is growing.  Still there are quite significant shock possibilities to the downside.  The largest of these is the potential losses of Gibraltar and Ireland. 
Personally when I see the EU supporting this idea..  I just have to go.. "Say what??????" Fitch's downgrade means that within 2 years it has a 50% chance of further downgrade.   The only factor cited was the budget.   That said, I have't reviewed UK fiscal policy to see if they have abandoned their debt reduction program.   But casual impression says not.  50% in 2 years means 12% chance in this time period....4% or so chance of an upgrade, dependent on budget review. Casual review of deficit says UK is making good progress on deficit reduction.  https://www.ukpublicspending.co.uk/uk_national_deficit_analysis  This says that swings are to the upside.    Moodies recently released expectations to the upside:
https://www.moodys.com/credit-ratings/United-Kingdom-Government-of-credit-rating-788250 Soooo  Here are the factors as I see them 1.  Brexit negotiations 
 a).  Financial (Banking Sector)
 b)   Ireland
 C).  Gibraltar.

3.  Change of government.   I don't see any ratings change till after the next election.   (May).  
Finally,  Dates for review.  As schedule  Fitch:  April 27, Moodies Jun 15,  S&P Oct 26.
Therefore for now, 100% no change.

The Brexit talks seem to be going more smoothly these days.  Also, solidarity among Western countries indicates greater cooperation in the future as long as Russia remains bellicose.  Having said that, I still think whatever economic relations result due to the negotiations will not favor the UK and the S&P credit rating will reflect that.

Strange days--they are beating expectations in revenues and budget controls and growth, but expectations were very low to begin with, so this mayn't mean much.  Also, services appear to be declining in availability and quality, which bodes ill for future growth.  And there's still the possibility of catastrophic Brexit.  This would probably keep the Chancellor awake at night, except he doesn't appear to be awake even in the daytime....
Going a little more negative despite recent economic news. Think mid term economic news won’t be as positive.

S&P does not make changes to rating rashly so there typically is a bit of inertia.  As others have pointed out, passions in teh UK for leaving the EU seems to have moderated and there does not seem to be pressure for anyone negotiating to make a quick decision on the future of the UK's relationship with Europe.

The British seem very ambivalent about Brexit, and the confusion and weakness seen in the current government seem to raise the chances of a disorderly exit or no exit. I think things being dragged out through the end of the year is more likely than the UK actually getting its act together and negotiating favorable exit terms. There seems to be an outside possibility that the British could think better of the whole idea and decide to drop it.

S&P stated they could downgrade if UK gets bad deal with EU over brexit or if foreign capital leaves  https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-britain-economy-rating/sp-fitch-leave-uk-credit-rating-on-hold-but-warn-on-brexit-idUKKBN1CW2WZ EU and UK "hope" to get deal by end of October, but these things drag out. UK and EU get a deal by Sep 30 is 50%, then bad deal 75% so bad deal*deal = 37.5%
Odds of investors withdrawal of capital, and don't see large FX fluctuation in EUR/GBP
https://tradingeconomics.com/eurgbp:cur and a strengthening of GBP/USD. So would put this risk at less than 25%.

With BREXIT negotiations unlikely to have unfolded before Sept. 2018, it is hard to see S&P upgrade its forecast.
Most likely for downgrade agencies to stay put within the time frame of the question, unless there is a genuinely very bad news impacting the UK. But forecasts over such short horizons usually stable.

My base case is no adjustment. I think a hard brexit could cause a downside adjustment although that's not a given in the time horizon of the question. In light oif the brexit overhang believe there is as good as zero probability of a upgrade in the mentioned time horizon

AA with negative outlook currently, but only one review scheduled before September. Inflation and growth largely predictable that far out, passage of time and expected lower UK GDP growth due to lower net immigration put growth risks (and forward projections) to the downside. No rating agency has a lower number though and maybe need a proper trigger to go further.
The poor progress on the Brexit will put pressure on rating agencies to evaluate the UK's standing.
Given the timeline, negotiation within British Parliament, and no set start date with the EU as to a concrete move... all is to lay stagnant... til further notice
Brits seem disorganized. Going heavier on “down” given S&P already gave a warning of sorts. Not very transparent info from Brits on exit and EU playing hardball.

As Brexit impacts on this question I am adding a Brexit comment here.
David Davis today said that 
"Britain will seek to stay close to the European Union’s rulebook in some areas, while aiming to break away quickly in a few others. The key tool to ensure U.K.-EU trade is as smooth as possible would be the “mutual recognition” of each other’s regulatory regimes, under the British plan. This idea -- in which each side agrees that the other’s separate system of rules is acceptable -- would also help solve the riddle of the Irish border, according to Brexit Secretary David Davis." I believe (but if anyone understands this subject better than I do please correct me) that this is mistaken view. "EU Mutual Recognition" has nothing to do with trade deals per se. A number of countries have "Mutual Recognition" deals with the EU including the USA, which has no EU Trade Deal. "EU Mutual Recognition" means there are " Mutual recognition agreements lay down the conditions under which one Party (non-member country) will accept conformity assessment results (e.g. testing or certification) performed by the other's Party (the EU) designated conformity assessment bodies (CABs) to show compliance with the first Party's (non-member country) requirements and vice versa. MRAs include relevant lists of designated laboratories, inspection bodies and conformity assessment bodies in both the EU and the third country." In other words it is nothing to do with the country (the UK in this case) maintaining the same internal regulations as the EU, but it is about UK labs being able to certify that UK produced goods conform to EU standards and so can ne exported there. No nothing to do with "mad max" scenarios.  I do not see how this solves the Irish border issue. If truck or van drives up the border it will still be necessary to confirm that the goods on that vehicle have the EU conformity test certifications in just the same was as goods from the USA would require certification. So in my opinion what Davis said today is meaningless, of course goods going to the EU have to conform to EU standards, "mutual Recognition" does not mean the EU will accept goods that conform to just UK standards.

The idea of a no-deal Brexit is now being spoken of by MPs as not going to happen and Labour MPs seem to think that the Labour Party official policy is likely at some point to come out in favour of staying in the Single Market/Customs Union. If Labour does make it policy and if most Labour MPs support the policy (most Party members apparently do, there are likely to be enough MPs from other parties, including Conservatives to force the government to also do so. In which case I would not expect S&P to downgrade their rating. But there are still quite a few "ifs" that could go wrong.
I believe there is possibility that Brexit is abandoned - several Brexiteers have said that a Brexit that left the UK in the SM/CU would not be worth having. So if this turned out to be the only form of Brexit that the government could get passed in Parliament it is possible that the Brexiteers would turn against the only Brexit on offer. In which case the UK economy could surge as delayed investment occurred.

In 2013, Moody’s cut the UK’s credit rating from Aaa to Aa1. After the Brexit vote, in June 2016 S&P cut the UK’s rating from AAA to AA (2 notches), Fitch cut from AA+ to AA, and Moody’s cut the outlook to negative.  In September 2017, Moody’s downgraded from Aa1 to Aa2 with a stable outlook, stating that Brexit was creating economic uncertainty, exacerbating the UK’s poor progress on debt reduction. Moody’s explained that the UK was increasing spending on health and social care, among other areas.  In October 2017, S&P and Fitch both reaffirmed their AA ratings, both with a negative outlook. Specifically, S&P cited that further downgrades might follow if there’s an increase in the likelihood of a disorderly Brexit or if overseas investors withdraw capital that finances the UK’s current account deficit. Fitch mentioned the lack of a clear British position, the EU stance, and limited time before the 29 March 2019 departure date are looking unfavorable for the UK.  Additionally, May’s substantially weakened position after the snap 2017 election created uncertainty over any long-term implementation. The Reuters article provides a direct rating agency quote “We believe that no single post-brexit relationship with the EU commands either majority parliamentary or popular support.” Both sides appear to favor a ‘transition period’ after March 2019 through 2020 for more time to work out the details. It appears that the transition period must be agreed to before the real negotiations on future relations can be addressed.  With just over 13 months to go before the deadline, this looks steep.  I expect that barring substantial news of progress, or with significant deterioration in the global economic outlook, I’ll be gradually increasing my forecasted likelihood of a downgrade. http://www.bbc.com/news/business-41369239
http://www.bbc.com/news/business-36644934

http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-32810887
BREXIT it has the  Country divided
The lack of a cohesive plan by the British government will lead to a downgrade but will that be withing the time frame?
Theresa Maybe will show what a leader she may be and may be do nothing. Maybe. The Brits need to clone Maggie and bring her back!
It was Brussels sprouted punishment,  and will be threatened again.

With Brexit talks going so slowly, the international economy staying relatively strong and stable, and the potential for the UK to back out or take a softer stance on Brexit, the wait and see position will stay for a long time.

With the exit still not complete there will be speculation about the effects on the UK's economy but no real effects that can't be acted on  (banking tax reforms etc.)  before the full exit. There will be stages of market volatility but not enough to effect a downgrade.
The likelihood of a smooth Brexit exit is low.  Little will happen to smooth that out before next September.

The stakes are high as I do not believe in my limited experience that a modern Western democracy has been downgraded below AA unless they were experiencing a significant financial and capital crisis. Despite the dysfunction we've seen so far from the UK leadership, the divisions within their parliament, and the failure of overseas support from the US to materialize in substantiating trade agreements, the UK simply can not risk a downgrade of their credit. Given this imperative and the lack of historical precedent, I expect they will remain status quo for now.
It is messy and it will get messier.
The current unstable situation is baked into the current rating.
Looming Brexit issues will still be unresolved
Ms. May is a disaster and her government may fail before the deadlines leading to a downgrade.
The U.K. will make its way through the economic maze, having already inflicted most of the damage on itself that it could with its political decision.
More businesses keep moving out of Britain.

The S & P rating is most likely to stay at AA given the overall unlikelihood of rating changes. Nevertheless, the risk of a bad Brexit deal or general loss of confidence does mean that there is heightened chance of a change. Conversely, news of a positive deal for the UK could well push rating back up though at less likelihood as no doubt they will want to wait until ratification is complete (post-March 2019)

Regarding the Brexit risk;
Macron's visit to the UK and his interview with Andrew Marr has (again) confirmed the likely Brexit outcome. Or at least the probable options. The media have added some spin to what Macron said which can be ignored. The two options on offer to the UK will be (a) a free trade deal excluding services (specifically financial services) similar to Canada (b) a deal similar to Norway that could include financial services and could include being in the Customs Union. 
The problem with (a) is that it does not offer any answer to how the agreement that the border between the UK and Ireland will have no controls (in practice introducing 3rd country controls on most UK borders with the EU would be a massive problem and cost), and it does not help the UK's need for full access to the EU Single Market. Polls are indicating that most voters want the UK to remain in the Single Market and Customs Union. So this (the "Canada" option seems less likely to be chosen by the UK) Option (b) which would be "Norway+, (or EEA, or EU minus)" in the Single Market, in the Customs Union (which Norway is not) and to all intents and purposes would be almost exactly the same as being in the EU. This would solve the Irish Border problem and could solve the Financial Services issue. The problem for the UK Government would be that it would require payments to the EU to continue, 3rd party free trade deals could not be made by the UK and the UK would be subject to EFTA Court (which is pretty similar to the ECJ.  None of the options would give the UK what Mrs May said she wanted because what she said she wants is contradictory. "No border checks" is impossible unless the UK is in the same Single Market and Customs Union. In order for the UK to be in a Single Market and Customs Union with the EU that did not have the ECJ as its Court all 27 other countries in the EU would need to agree to changing how the EU's Single Market and Customs Union is structured. There appears to be zero chance of that happening.  The direction of travel suggests that option (b) is the most likely to end up being agreed. Few voters seem to believe that Mrs May will be able get a good Brexit deal. In this the voters seem a lot more realistic that the UK Government. So given that 65% of voters are not expecting a good deal it can be assumed that being faced with two options neither of which actually meets what Mrs May wants, they will expect the government to choose the least bad option. 
Option (a) is likely to lead to voters in N. Ireland demanding a referendum on uniting with Eire, which could lead to N. Ireland leaving the UK, which could encourage Scotland to do the same. According to (almost) all economic studies option (a) would cause more economic damage (including an S&P Downgrade). 
Option (b) would mean less known economic damage but would not give the perceived advantages of leaving the EU   (i.e. it would be pointless) but to reject (b) would require voters to believe what the Brexiteers told them. Having previously told voters that the EU would give exactly the same friction less access to the EU as  being a member did, but with the ability to do 3rd party trade deals, no payments, no freedom of movement etc. and that doing such a deal would "take an afternoon" because it was "the easiest trade deal in history", would voters believe them? So I think Brexit risk is already included in S&P's view, what might not be is the possibility of another economic crisis due to the cumulative effect of spending cuts of public services forcing public spending to rise and/or the collapse of zombie businesses that have only been able to keep going by cutting investment and borrowing cheap money. I don't think the UK's economic fundamentals look good.  
If on the other hand the UK unexpectedly abandoned Brexit there could be an investment boom.  http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-42757026
https://www.standard.co.uk/news/politics/majority-back-continued-single-market-membership-after-brexit-new-poll-finds-a3744116.html
https://whatukthinks.org/eu/questions/if-a-second-eu-referendum-were-held-today-how-would-you-vote/
https://whatukthinks.org/eu/questions/how-confident-or-not-are-you-that-theresa-may-can-secure-a-good-brexit-deal-for-the-uk/
Brexit effect on Brits economy and EU uncertainty of how it will impact the EU
I hear negotiations are not going well.  Now the failure of Carillion ($2B debt to start) will affect UK’s debt/expenditures... it has to affect their rating.

There could be be fallout from the Carillion liquidation.  PFI contracts were seen as a way of keeping public debts off the UK's books, so that capital expenditure on public sector projects could be converted into operating expenditure and not show as part of the UK National Debt. The collapse of Carillian (will/might?) expose that ultimately the UK state would face liabilities when a PFI contractor fails. There have been questions asked as to how big the total PFI debts are; the UK Government does not seem to have the figures. 
It is part of the nature of financial scares that some seemingly small, contained event, prompts markets to take another look at wider cases and then realise that what had appeared to be an isolated failure is more systemic than had been accounted for. If in looking at Carillion markets notice that there are lots of "safe" PFI companies (and other types of companies) that have huge levels of borrowing and that when companies that rely of chains of subcontractors to do their work go bust then that ripples through the construction chain (subcontractors who were owned money might also go bust, material suppliers might go bust.)  
Maybe the Carillion failure can be contained but there is a risk that it could be a much bigger problem than it appears, and if it pushes up UK National Debt it could trigger a revision to the UK credit rating.  It could also in the longer term mean that there are calls for businesses to be more financed by equity rather than debt,
This is a toss-up, S&P someone will wake-up on the wrong side of the bed / right side and there you go ... no downgrade until next year...

Base case.
According to my reckoning from data here:  (https://www.capitaliq.com/CIQDotNet/CreditResearch/RenderArticle.aspx?articleId=1894459&SctArtId=433768&from=CM&nsl_code=LIME&sourceObjectId=9636657&sourceRevId=20&fee_ind=N&exp_date=20270804-21:15:37) there are 23 occasions when S&P has changed the rating of a G10 country. The average number of days between changes is 4933. There are only 258 days left until the deadline for this question so the possibility of any G10 country having its rating changed is somewhere in the region of 258/4933 or 5%. For any individual country (there are apparently 11 countries in the G10) we have approximately ½% chance of a change. 18 changes are downgrades and 5 are upgrades. Obviously this is extremely rough and ready.  Inside case. 
What would affect the UK’s rating? S&P’s Moritz Kraemer had this to say: “The very strong cohesion and predictablility of policy making which has been a hallmark of for UK politics for decades is, for the first time in decades, at the risk of being weakened.” This gives us a very strong hint that at this stage S&P are focussed on governance rather than any immediate concerns about the UK meeting its obligations. With no general election or referendum in the offing, and May keeping her rivals close to her, my take is that we are in a period of relative political stability until 30th September 2018. However that’s only relative to 2016 and 2017, so I’ll be raising the base rate and taking account of the historical bias that has downgrades outnumbering upgrades by more than 3 to 1.
The correction is coming either way.

From S&P's update on 27-Oct-2017: The negative outlook reflects the continued institutional and economic 
uncertainty surrounding the Brexit negotiations and the U.K.'s future 
relationship with the EU after the country's departure from the bloc in March 
2019. We could lower the ratings if any of the following scenarios materialize: We view the risk of a disorderly Brexit as increasingly certain.  The U.K.'s income levels, as measured by GDP per capita in U.S. dollar 
terms, weaken markedly and we believe they are unlikely to revert to 
higher levels for some time. Capital inflows, which finance the U.K.'s large current account deficit, 
dry up or reverse. In our opinion, such outflows or lower external 
financing would ultimately affect growth in the U.K., not least by having 
a dampening influence on capital accretion and productivity. We also 
believe that lower financing inflows would be symptomatic of the waning of
the U.K.'s global importance for key sectors, such as financial services. The budgetary position weakens markedly beyond our current expectations. Significant constitutional challenges arise, particularly related to a 
second independence referendum in Scotland or to increased tensions 
regarding Northern Ireland.
No trade agreement with EU means rating cut
With Brexit around the corner i see the economy getting weaker instead of stronger.
Too much at stake for both sides not to come up with an orderly Brexit. So if 'orderly', then rating goes up.
The brexit final agreement is getting clearer  (and softer) by the day, mainly because of the irish border issue.
No matter How, no matter When, no matter with whom... The UK-EU Brexit deal will be done and therefore no S&P adjustements would be necessary.
It's still a major economy with stability in mind for business, only would go down if a no-deal brexit is guaranteed
If Brexit talks continue to stall expect a downgrade this year
Brexit is good for the UK economy.

A move up or down at this point would likely require some sort of economic shakeup that shows whether Great Britains exit was wise or not, though fears of a disorderly exit may make a down-grade more likely than an upgrade.  As for if a shakeup will occur, it's coming.  Soon.  But exactly when, who knows.

Its likely to go down before it comes up again! its unlikely confidence will increase without long term evidence of economic improvements. It make take many years to gain equilibrium in this new economy that will emerge.

If the Brexit negotiations proceed a little more smoothly the the UK they might get a temporary bump up or stabilization in their credit rating, but in the long run the costs of Brexit to the UK from a macro perspective will only become clearer globalization critics notwithstanding.

S&P is a forecast itself. This means they can adapt their result later on to the next political decisions. That's why I assume that they will simply wait and see. On the other hand, recent negotions were not that successful. They are simply running out of time.
I think any adjustment in Q1-Q3 of 2018 will be unlikely. They are more inclined to put the UK on their watch list before making any adjustment.
Brexit will hit the United Kingdom hard.
A downward rating seems more likely than an improvement. But any change before late 2018 seems too early.

Coming a bit back to the consensus. I still think Brexit was a stupid idea (at least economically) and thus an increase of status is simply out of the question. You can't go around and telling people that you owe money can go whistle and have that improve your credit rating (yes I know it's not exactly the same) Nevertheless right now there is little effect to be observed. While I think this is mostly a yet, it might be that by further delaying the "final settlement" both sides will put up enough dust so that no rating agency will adjust their rating. So it might be that the September cutoff is too early.
Don't know what Brexit is doing these days
Don’t expect changes unless talks break down.

Great Britain will be penalized for this unwise economic movement based more on cultural politics than rational economic judgment.  The US and other allies of Great Britain will help it maintain some stability only because of its long-term relationships.
A long and disorderly Brexit likely.
This is not my real whatsoever.
The 'sufficient progress' of phase one brexit talks reduces the chances of a hard brexit and hence a ratings downgrade. Still a high hurdle to getting an upgrade
Inflation is rising and Brexit looms large. If there is an adjustment it may be on the downward side but the economy has proven surprisingly resilient thus far.
May will negotiate and obtain good terms. No reason for revision.
The exit seems to be going smoothly. I do not expect that to change.
Now that Brexit negotiations are moving on to the next phase, I think the situation has stabilized in terms of credit agencies.
Brexit has too many scenario outcomes and the chance to call an incorrect outlook and thereby credit rating too risky for SP - high probability for no change

If the UK and EU agree a transition agreement of 2 years (or with no specific end date) that is as described already by the EU (e.g. in Single Market and Customs Union under ECJ) it would mean the Brexiteers do not have the power and/or will to stop it, which would mean that a similar agreement could become the permanent relationship between the EU and UK then the UK's economy might pick up growth and repair the UK finances.
Reality will produce a sensible climb down...

S&P says could lower the rating on U.K. if GDP per capita (in U.S. dollar terms) or public finances weaken markedly beyond S&P's current expectations 
https://www.reuters.com/article/brief-sp-says-ratings-on-the-united-king/brief-sp-says-ratings-on-the-united-kingdom-affirmed-at-aa-a-1-idUSFWN1I017D Standard and Poor's said on Friday its credit rating for the United Kingdom was not immediately affected by the latest agreement between Britain and the European Union to move Brexit talks on to trade and a transition period. The ratings agency said it stuck with its "AA" credit rating with a negative outlook.
http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-5159963/S-P-UK-credit-rating-not-immediately-affected-EU-talks-deal.html

If the Conservatives can hold on to power, I don't think Britain's macroeconomic outlook is so, so dire. I also think that the UK and the EU need each other too much for any chaotic separation to go unaddressed for too long. The real risk is Corbyn getting into power. He could really bungle fiscal policy, leading to credit downgrades, especially if bad policy coincides with economic turbulence from abroad.

Very much depending on how the Brexit negotiations go. I cannot foresee a triple A rating shift. I don't think a downgrade will occur until after October 2018 if the Brexit deal influences it further.
Yesterday agreement will be perceived as a very good outcome for economically. But it is early for a an up.

Based on the recent outcome of the UK-Eu negotiations, I think it will be very difficult to have a downgrade within this timeframe. March 2018 is the "point of no return" for any contingency plans from big companies stationed in the UK. In case of signs of hard Brexit, brace yourselves.

Rating will be upgraded in an unlikely positive scenario wherein Brexit decision is reversed; there will be no change to the rating in case UK and EU agree to a reasonable deal (more probable than the previous scenario); the rating will be downgraded in either of these cases (hence higher probability): a) leadership change in UK leading to more uncertainty b) deal not favorable to UK in either short or long term c) reasonable deal, but a with a high 'divorce' bill for the UK.
I foresee  a hard Brexit and very big turmoil... ( but hope Brittain finds a decent wY out of Brexit, without too much losing face)
It is not enough time for sovereign review unless something as bis as an earth shattering event takes place.
The Brexit has shown a tendency to lower UK economic outlook, this can only change if EU gives a good deal to UK, and that seems unlikely.

A deal with the EU (all 27 EU countries need to approve) is close to impossible. That is extremely damaging for the UK economy and it will lead to ongoing political instability, which is probably even more important.
This will change as the intervening 10 months occur.
Brexit takes a bite out of British economy especially if no agreement is reached with the E.U.

An UP if the UK scrapped Brexit (unlikely in this timeframe but not impossible)
DOWN if the UK walked out of the Brexit negotiations or looked like failing to get a deal. 
Also DOWN if there was signs of a mass exodus of tax generating businesses from the UK (e.g. the banks, media companies, manufacturers)
Brexit impacts generally built in to current ratings, I suspect.
S&P won’t likely have enough new information to make an adjustment.

The Brexit talks have been progressing at a snail's pace, with the British government not being able to even agree internally on their goals. However, I don't see the UK's credit rating falling any further or rising anytime soon unless the talks go tremendously badly or well. Even then, I believe S&P will wait to see the final deal before making any adjustments.

The process (which feels generous) of Brexit has not been going well and I don't see that changing anytime soon. Unless negotiations start soon on a trade deal I see this process only getting messier.

Having already stripped Britain of its top-notch “AAA” rating, both agencies stuck with their “AA” rating with a negative outlook, warning they were likely to downgrade again. “The negative outlook reflects the continued institutional and economic uncertainty surrounding the Brexit negotiations and the UK’s future relationship with its largest market for goods and services, the EU,” S&P said in a statement. 
https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-britain-economy-rating/sp-fitch-leave-uk-credit-rating-on-hold-but-warn-on-brexit-idUKKBN1CW2WZ?utm_source=34553&utm_medium=partner Bizarre is this an English comprehension test? S & P already stated they would most likely downgrade. S & P has issued no upgrades, in regards to the UK. Recent history is pretty clear on the outcome.
Very unlikely a significant enough change happens to warrant a rating change. If so, equally likely to be up or down.
